intro: Hicriopteris volubilis, commonly known as the climbing fern, is a species of fern characterized by its long, creeping rhizomes that allow it to climb and spread across surfaces. It features fronds that are typically divided into narrow, linear segments, giving it a delicate, lace-like appearance. The plant thrives in moist, shaded environments, often found in forests and along stream banks. Its spores are produced in small, clustered sporangia located on the underside of the fronds. Hicriopteris volubilis plays an important ecological role by contributing to soil stabilization and providing habitat for various small organisms.
